notesStmt.note: Italian inscription stating that this is the first volume of a three-volume Bible and that it was written in 'Castion' in mese Elul in anno 5105 (1345) e la scrittura di Ezra figlio di Jacob Adorat (these data correspond with the colophon in Harley 5775, 121,([2v]).
Manuscript description based on Margoliouth, G.: Catalogue of the Hebrew and Samaritan Manuscripts in the British Museum, London 1965.

msContents.summary: Pentateuch, Hafṭarot and Five Scrolls, provided with punctuation, accents, masorah magna and parva. Aka the 'London Catalan Pentateuch'.

collation.p: 32 quires: i-xv8 (folios 1-120), xvi10+2 (folios 121-132), xvii10 (folios 133-142), xviii-xx10 (folios 143-162), xxi-xxiii6 (folios 163-172), xxiv9 (folios 179-187), xxv10-2 (folios 188-195), xxvi8 (folios 196-203), xxvii-xxxi8 (folios 204-243), xxxii5 (folios 244-248).

scriptDesc.scriptNote: Sefardi square script, punctuated, of the last quarter of the 14th century.

decoDesc.decoNote: Numerous micrographical designs. Numerous decorated parashah signs, in ink. Pen drawing of a castle.

history.provenance: Acquisition: John Covel (b. 1638, d. 1722), chaplain to the Levant Company at Constantinople: in his collection (no. VIII.): inscribed ([1r]). His manuscripts were acquired for the Harley Collection for £300 in 1716; Latin inscription: de accurate Bibliorum Hebrais. .. (18th century?).

Acquisition: Edward Harley: bought by him together with Covel's other manuscripts, for £300 on 27 February 1715/6 (). The Harley Collection, formed by Robert Harley (b. 1661, d. 1724), 1st earl of Oxford and Mortimer, politician, and Edward Harley (b. 1689, d. 1741), 2nd earl of Oxford and Mortimer, book collector and patron of the arts. Edward Harley bequeathed the library to his widow, Henrietta Cavendish, née Holles (b. 1694, d. 1755) during her lifetime and thereafter to their daughter, Margaret Cavendish Bentinck (b. 1715, d.1785), duchess of Portland; the manuscripts were sold by the Countess and the Duchess in 1753 to the nation for £10,000 (a fraction of their contemporary value) under the Act of Parliament that also established the British Museum; the Harley manuscripts form one of the foundation collections of the British Library.
